docs.title: Tengu (Raptor-folk)
docs.text:
The Tengu are bird-like humanoids who embody the darker, more aggressive aspects of their avian lineage. While the Garukkan exhibit sociability and pride, the Tengu embrace tenacity, independence, and cunning with a more ominous undertone. Known for their eloquence and intelligence, Tengu are highly self-assured, with a significant ego that often leads to isolation from others, even within their own kind. Unlike the Garukkan, who enjoy mingling with other societies, the Tengu view the world with suspicion and prefer to operate alone or in small, tightly knit groups. Tengu are natural predators, and some are known to resolve conflicts with lethal efficiency. Tengu society is loosely structured, lacking a true sense of community, as most members act according to personal codes of honor or vendettas. These dark, solitary beings are rarely seen in friendly terms with other cultures and are often feared or misunderstood for their ruthlessness and fierce independence.

Skills: Acrobatics, Detection, Athletics, Brawl, Finesse, Survival, Communication, Throw. Personality traits: Aggressive, Ambitious, Competitive, Fearless, Proud (Pretentious), Rebellious, Opportunistic, Energetic, Reckless, Independent.

Strong attributes: Intelligence (x2), Perception, Cunning −− Intelligence (x2) – Tengu are sharp, analytical thinkers, obsessively dissecting tactics, grudges, and rivalries; their minds are honed for strategy and calculated conflict. −− Perception – As raptors, they possess razor-sharp sight and awareness, spotting weaknesses, movements, and distant targets with ease. −− Cunning – Ambitious, competitive, and ruthless, Tengu are excellent strategists on a small scale—duels, ambushes, and personal vendettas. Weak attributes: Constitution, Luck −− Constitution – Lean and built for speed rather than durability, Tengu do not handle prolonged punishment or attrition as well as sturdier ferals. −− Luck – Their arrogance, reckless choices, and appetite for conflict attract retaliation and misfortune: they often create their own downfall. Birth attributes: Stature 8~10, Height 9~10, Ego 10~12, Appearance 8~10, Luck 8~10, Balance 10~12 (Prefered) Allegiance: Neutral, Dreams, Reason, Sciences Living environment: Marine, Mountain, Forest Nature: Predatory. docs.title: Razkkan
docs.text:
The Skaven are rat-like humanoids living in tunnels, ruins, and hidden areas. They are highly cunning and ruthless, with a society driven by personal gain and constant infighting. Known for their stealth, larceny, and survival skills, Skaven are adept at infiltration and scavenging, often using poisons, diseases, and crude technologies to their advantage. They rarely cooperate with others and are notorious for betrayal.

Skills: Larceny, Subterfuge, Occultism, Discretion, Detection, Urban Life, Investigation, Brawl. Personality traits: ?.

Strong attributes: Agility, Cunning, Perception −− Agility – Razkkan skitter through ruins, sewers, and tunnels with ease, climbing, dodging and fleeing in tight, hazardous spaces. −− Cunning – Their entire society revolves around schemes, betrayals, and self-interest. Every Razkkan learns to think crooked to survive. −− Perception – Used to filth, darkness, and unstable environments, they are quick to notice cracks, sounds, movement, and exploitable details others miss. Weak attributes: Willpower, Luck −− Willpower – Addiction to power, fear, and paranoia make them easy prey to domination, panic, or mass hysteria. −− Luck – Surrounded by disease, collapsing lairs, treachery and dangerous experiments, Razkkan are almost cosmically unlucky—only their cunning keeps them alive. docs.title: Urssian (Grizzly-folk)
docs.text:
The Urssian are a feral ethnicity similar to the Koddans, but with a more aggressive and violent culture. Known for their sheer physical strength and a social structure that values might above all, Urssians believe that power determines status and respect. They are often found in rugged, mountainous regions, where they maintain a life of endurance and combat readiness. Conflict and displays of dominance are central to their way of life.

Skills: Melee, Defense, Endurance, Athletics, Craftsmanship, Detection, Rural Life, Tactical. Personality traits: Stoic, Imposing, Aggressive, Loyal, Protective (Alert), Hardworking, Stubborn, Serious, Cautious, Resentful.

Strong attributes: Strength, Constitution (x2) −− Strength – Urssians are walking siege engines: their physical might surpasses most ferals and allows devastating blows in combat. −− Constitution (x2) – Their bodies are built to endure cold, injuries, and exhaustion. They can keep fighting, working, or traveling long after others fall. −− Willpower – Their culture of dominance and endurance forges unbending resolve; once an Urssian commits to a course, turning back is rare. Weak attributes: Luck −− Luck – Their culture of constant confrontation and dominance invites trouble—feuds, grudges, and brutal trials often stack the odds against them, even when they win. docs.text:

We will then speak of minor feral ethnicity and in these cases it is proposed to use the profile of an equivalent major ethnicity.

docs.title: Halfling
docs.text:
Halflings are small folk gifted with a disarming youthful appearance that makes suspicion slip right past them. Their round faces, bright eyes, and lively manners suggest innocence—even when they are far from it. This lack of perceived threat is both a blessing and a curse: they avoid trouble easily, yet they are rarely taken seriously, even when they should be.

Living mostly among human societies—and, more rarely, elven ones—Halflings blend effortlessly into larger cultures, adapting to their customs while keeping their own traditions mostly unspoken. A long-standing rumor claims they have a homeland of their own, a hidden place of green hills and cozy burrows. Halflings themselves speak of it fondly, yet none can say if it truly exists. They were taught never to seek it, as if the myth itself mattered more than the truth; a story they cling to for comfort, identity, or perhaps something deeper.

Behind their cheerful faces lie sharp instincts for survival, negotiation, and quiet mischief—traits born from a life lived on the edge of obscurity.

Skills: Persuasion, Discretion, Acrobatics, Larceny, Survival, Negotiation, Finesse, Communication. Personality traits: Friendly, Playful, Optimistic, Curious, Resourceful, Homebound, Community-minded, Indulgent, Talkative (Loudmouth), Avoidant.

Strong attributes: Dexterity, Agility, Cunning, Luck (x2) −− Dexterity – Small hands, nimble fingers, and a natural talent for subtle manipulation make Halflings excellent pickpockets, cooks, tinkerers, and lockbreakers. −− Agility – Light, quick, soft-footed, and unpredictable, they move gracefully through crowds and tight spaces that larger folk cannot navigate. −− Luck (x2) – Fortune truly seems to love them. Coin flips, daring escapes, risky gambles, and improbable coincidences routinely go their way. −− Cunning – Their innocent appearances conceal quick thinking. Halflings understand people, twist situations to their advantage, and improvise solutions in charmingly sneaky ways. Weak attributes: Strength, Constitution, Charisma, Willpower −− Strength – Small stature means little raw power. They rely on agility and cleverness, not force. −− Constitution – They are not built for hard labor, prolonged suffering, or harsh climates; they prefer comfort and safety. −− Charisma – They are liked, yes, but not respected. Their childish looks and carefree manners make it hard for others to take them seriously. −− Willpower – Halflings avoid conflict, trouble, and responsibilities. Their indulgent habits and reluctance to commit make them less resistant to manipulation or pressure. Birth attributes: Stature 8~9, Height 6~7, Ego 7~10, Appearance 10~12, Luck 10~13, Balance 6~10 (Prefered) Allegiance: Neutral, Chaos, Dreams, Ambition Living environment: Rural or City-dwelling Family: Small Folks Nature: Impure Beings

docs.title: Dryavid / Treefolks
docs.text:
Dryavids are beings of living wood and sap, guardians of secluded groves and ancient spirits. They coexist closely with Sylvanian elves, sharing values, culture, and an intimate reverence for the forest. While Dryavids understand elven society, they rarely partake in it fully, preferring the quiet sanctuaries hidden deep within the wilderness.

Their temperament contrasts sharply with that of their long-standing counterparts, the Nymphs. Though both peoples embody nature, they do so through very different philosophies. Dryavids are direct, unwavering, and at times uncompromising—living embodiments of the forest's immutable laws. Nymphs, on the other hand, tend to be fluid, playful, charming, and subtly unpredictable.

This divergence often leads to a gentle rivalry: Dryavids view Nymphs as overly capricious and lacking discipline, while Nymphs see Dryavids as overly rigid and humorless. These tensions are rarely hostile, but they shape centuries of cultural teasing, disagreements, and competitive pride between the two races.

Despite this, when the forest is threatened, Dryavids stand among its fiercest protectors, wielding ancient strength and deep-rooted resolve.

Not to be confused with treants, which is a monstrous version of this people.

Skills: Spellcasting, Survival, Meditation, Craftsmanship, Erudition, Defense, Hunting, Subterfuge. Personality traits: Calm, Patient, Conservative, Community-minded, Principled, Serious, Forgiving, Warm, Measured, Cautious.

Strong attributes: Constitution, Wisdom Weak attributes: None Birth attributes: Stature 10~11, Height 9~10, Ego 10~11, Appearance 8~10, Luck 10, Balance 10~11 (Prefered) Allegiance: Neutral, Nature, Silence, Heritage Living environment: Forest Family: Small Folks Nature: Pure or Impure Beings

docs.title: Celestial
docs.text:
Celestials are radiant beings who dwell high above Thalifen on floating islands where order, law, and discipline form the core of civilization. They do not concern themselves with moral “good,” but rather with absolute order, which they see as the foundation of existence. Their society is rigid and structured, where every action is regulated and every transgression is a sacrilege.

Those who violate these sacred rules face exile—a punishment more severe than death for a Celestial. Most inhabitants of Thalifen have only ever encountered these exiles, for the Celestial realm remains almost entirely inaccessible to mortals. Even stripped of their status, exiled Celestials often retain the pride and aloofness of their people, viewing the world below as chaotic, primitive, and unbearably undisciplined.

Yet exceptions exist. Throughout history, a handful of Celestials have forged meaningful bonds with terrestrial peoples, such as the famed Alluren, whose exile aided the creation of Sylvengarde. Some Celestials, like the Valkyries, even allow themselves to be venerated by mortal cultures, acting as martial spirits or divine emissaries.

A Celestial's presence commands respect, but behind their luminous beauty lies a mind shaped by strict doctrine—and a heart rarely given freely.

Skills: Spellcasting, Erudition, Defense, Tactical, Persuasion, Meditation, Leadership, Endurance. Personality traits: Serious, Principled, Conservative, Organized, Disciplined, Leader, Cold, Patient, Judgmental (Critical), Conformist.

Strong attributes: Charisma, Willpower (x2), Magic (x2) Weak attributes: Perception, Cunning Birth attributes: Stature 10, Height 10, Ego 11~13, Appearance 11~13, Luck 5~8, Balance 10~12 (Prefered) Allegiance: Neutral, Magic, Arcanes, Faith Living environment: City-dwelling, Urban, Rural Family: Divine Folks Nature: Pure Beings

docs.title: Fairies
docs.text:
Fairies are graceful, winged beings roughly half the height of a human—slightly taller than Halflings yet far lighter. They are whimsical, capricious, and irresistibly curious, embracing life as a kaleidoscope of sensations and emotions. Their moods shift with the wind: playful laughter one moment, spiteful mischief the next.

Though often charming, Fairies are known for their volatile tempers and their notorious inability to accept defeat. A fairy scorned may unleash a cascade of pranks, illusions, or unsettling tricks—not deadly, but certainly memorable, and sometimes genuinely dangerous. The wrath of a Fairy, once provoked, can linger far longer than expected.

Their societies favor artistic expression, freedom, and the surreal logic of dreams. Fairies wander through forests and coastal regions, dancing between sunlight and moonbeams, shaping the world subtly with their magic. They are neither benevolent nor malevolent—merely true to their nature: emotional, impulsive, and endlessly enchanted by secrets and stories.

Not to be confused with pixies, which is a monstrous version of this people.

Skills: Spellcasting, Acrobatics, Discretion, Subterfuge, Persuasion, Negotiation, Finesse, Art. Personality traits: Playful, Spontaneous, Energetic, Expressive, Curious, Emotional (Sensitive), Reckless, Opportunistic, Indulgent, Loudmouth.

docs.title: Qunari
docs.text:
The Qunari are a horned people known for their imposing stature and austere discipline. Their society follows a rigid doctrine called the Line, which teaches that every individual—regardless of strength, age, or rank—is responsible for maintaining the cohesion of the whole. Leadership among the Qunari is not fixed by birth or authority but granted temporarily to those whose competence best suits the situation, making their hierarchy fluid, adaptive, and surprisingly egalitarian.

Communities gather around large communal halls where decisions are made collectively through structured, ritualized debate. Endurance—physical, mental, and moral—is the cornerstone of Qunari identity. Emotional restraint is considered a form of wisdom, and their philosophy, although not a religion, holds that life gains meaning through discipline, clarity of purpose, and stability.

Qunari rarely assimilate into foreign cultures, which they often perceive as chaotic or lacking in foundational rigor. Still, individuals who struggle with the Line—or who simply seek a different path—sometimes abandon their homeland, becoming wanderers, mercenaries, or diplomats of circumstance.

Despite their stoic exterior, Qunari are not emotionless. They simply shape their emotions as they shape their bodies. Even those of frail build are expected to cultivate strength of mind and duty. Outsiders often misinterpret their seriousness as humorless solemnity, yet Qunari communities prize a form of ritualized irony: a dry, expressionless wit exchanged without smiles—both a cultural bonding tool and a subtle test of intellect. To most foreigners, this is as incomprehensible as it is unsettling.

<> Qunaris possess what scholars call the Memory of Iron: Their horn structure contains dense mineral fibers that subtly vibrate in the presence of emotional tension. Trained Qunaris can “read” these vibrations in others of their kin, sensing anxiety, aggression, hesitation, or determination without a word spoken. This gives them exceptional synchronicity in combat formations and makes Qunari warbands notoriously difficult to outmaneuver.

Skills: Melee, Tactical, Endurance, Leadership, Defense, Athletics, Persuasion, Survival. Personality traits: Disciplined, Serious, Organized, Stoic, Leader, Conservative, Loyal, Measured, Cautious, Unshakeable.

docs.title: Nymphs
docs.text:
Nymphs are nature-born beings traditionally associated with forests, rivers, and glades. Though admired for their elegance, they are far from the idealized figures depicted in human folklore. Their culture is shaped by duality: gentleness and mischief, serenity and volatility. Nymphs value emotional expression as much as Dryavids value structure, creating a longstanding cultural tension between the two peoples.

In Nymph society, decisions are taken through circles, communal gatherings where opinions are weighed not by authority but by persuasive ability—a trait they cultivate rigorously from youth. They cherish beauty not as ornament, but as a form of truth, believing that aesthetics reflect the inner state of beings and environments.

Though peaceful in appearance, Nymphs possess a sharp sense of pride and can react strongly to disrespect or broken promises. Their relationships with outsiders tend to be selective: they are welcoming to those who show sensitivity to nature, yet distant or even playful-cruel toward those who do not.

Unlike Dryavids, who embody the stern, immutable laws of the forest, Nymphs represent its fluidity—its charm, its illusions, its gentler yet unpredictable rhythms. They embrace sensibility, diplomacy, and intuition, making them subtle negotiators and enchanting speakers. Their playful nature, however, masks a keen intellect and a deep understanding of the emotional currents around them. Tensions with Dryavids stem from these philosophical differences: Dryavids see Nymphs as too indulgent and whimsical, while Nymphs find Dryavids overly rigid and lacking in joy. Still, despite this rivalry, the two peoples stand united when nature calls for protectors.

<> Nymphs possess the Echo of Emotion: any strong feeling expressed near them leaves behind a faint, temporary impression—an echo—visible only to their senses. These echoes take the form of glimmers, subtle colors, or vibrations in the air, allowing Nymphs to read emotional “trails” left by others. This makes them extraordinary mediators… and dangerously insightful antagonists.

Skills: Spellcasting, Survival, Meditation, Craftsmanship, Defense, Finesse, Negotiation, Swimming. Personality traits: Warm, Expressive, Curious, Sensitive, Persuasive (Confident), Community-minded, Indulgent, Opportunistic, Reactive (Impatient), Bright.

docs.title: Trolls
docs.text:
Trolls are a nomadic horned people whose origins remain one of Thalifen's cultural enigmas. The few records that mention them describe their arrival from the far southern reaches of the world—lands believed lost to Morvivance. Whether they fled, migrated, or simply wandered remains unknown even to them, as Troll oral traditions are fragmented and contradictory.

Troll society is defined by absolute personal autonomy. They acknowledge no chiefs, masters, or formal structures; authority is a foreign concept to them. Cooperation arises organically through mutual respect or shared goals, and conflicts are resolved through debate, contests of wits, or ritual duels intended to defuse tension rather than establish dominance.

Highly adaptive, Trolls travel in small caravans or as lone wanderers, guided by instinct and a deep cultural belief that stagnation is a form of death. Their craftsmanship is unexpectedly refined, often using unusual materials collected during their travels. Outsiders find them difficult to categorize: simultaneously contemplative and fierce, hospitable and aloof, unpredictable yet bound by a strong sense of personal honor.

Because so few Trolls have been seen in Thalifen, they remain shrouded in speculation, often romanticized or misunderstood by scholars.

<> Trolls wield the Pulse of Chaos, a dormant resonance within their blood inherited from their forgotten homeland. This pulse reacts to powerful magic, emotional upheaval, or mortal danger, manifesting as flickers of colored light beneath their skin and granting them brief surges of instinctual clarity or strength.

Skills: Melee, Brawl, Endurance, Survival, Subterfuge, Defense, Tactical, Craftsmanship. Personality traits: Stoic, Enduring (Hardworking), Independent, Gloomy, Cautious, Resourceful, Patient, Principled, Quiet, Unshakeable.

docs.title: Naggan
docs.text:
Naggan are serpentfolk descended from ancient lineages that once thrived behind the protective walls of Rosaï. They are recognized by their serpentine tails, shimmering scales, and calm, deliberate manner of speech. Though humanoid in stature, their physical and spiritual heritage ties them deeply to the forgotten age when Primordial Dragons still brushed against the world.

Their society was once divided into several clans—each distinguished by scale coloration and cultural tradition. Many of these clans were decimated when Morvivance reached Rosaï, scattering survivors across Thalifen. Today, Naggan communities are small, secretive, and often hidden within remote societies where mistrust follows them like a shadow.

Naggan culture venerates the Primordial Dragons not as gods, but as archetypes of cosmic principles. Each clan interprets this devotion differently: some through shamanism, others through martial discipline, mysticism, or oratory tradition. Although most Naggan now live isolated lives, the old customs endure in fragments—songs, scales dyed in ritual pigments, meditative dances, and cryptic proverbs referencing the "Silenced Wyrms."

Despite their enigmatic aura, Naggan are not hostile; they are contemplative and pragmatic, their worldview shaped by the belief that destiny coils and uncoils like a serpent, unpredictable yet purposeful.

Some of most known naggan's clan are: Cindervale Clan — Black and ember-red scales : A warrior lineage known for strict discipline and controlled rage. They viewed destruction as a path to renewal, echoing the Ashen Serpent's teachings. Today, survivors wander as stoic mercenaries, bound by rigid personal honor. Glistenscale Clan — Iridescent blue and green scales : Mystics and shamans who practiced water-based divination and dream-trance rites. They believe memories flow like rivers and that the Primordials still whisper through them. Many now live near coasts or waterways. Sandcoil Clan — Gold and desert tones : Survivalists shaped by harsh environments, valuing patience, silence, and adaptability. Inspired by the Dune Wyrm, they mastered ambush tactics and desert navigation. Their remnants drift between remote desert communities. Verdancescale Clan — Green and earth-toned scales : Diplomats, negotiators, and keepers of social balance. Their ritual debates followed spiral patterns symbolizing growth and resolution. They integrate more easily into forest societies, though still as outsiders. Lumenscale Clan — White and pale lavender scales : Students of karmic flows, illusions, and hidden forces. Their insight is uncanny and often unsettling to others. They suffered greatly during Rosaï's fall, leaving only scattered scholars and occultists.

Not to be confused with nagas, which is a monstrous version of this people.

Skills: Spellcasting, Subterfuge, Melee, Persuasion, Survival, Tactical, Negotiation, Defense. Personality traits: Calm, Calculative, Secretive, Cautious, Opportunistic, Loyal, Disciplined, Measured, Independent, Curious.

docs.title: Centauran
docs.text:
Centaurans are an ancient semi-equine people whose culture blends warrior tradition with ritual wisdom. Proud and fiercely independent, they live in secluded forest enclaves where every aspect of life—craft, combat, diplomacy, even travel—is governed by elaborate customs passed down through long oral lineages. To outsiders, these customs often seem cryptic or overly formal, but to Centaurans they are the foundation of balance and honor.

Their society values strength of body as much as clarity of purpose. Centaurans rarely involve themselves in the affairs of other peoples, believing that most humanoids lack the discipline and respect necessary to navigate Centauran etiquette. Yet, when they choose to act, they do so with solemn conviction and strategic foresight.

Regarded as both protectors and omens by nearby communities, Centaurans maintain an aura of mystique. They act neither as sages nor savages—simply as guardians of their own path, bound to traditions older than most written histories.

Not to be confused with centaurs, which is a monstrous version of this people.

Skills: Melee, Tactical, Endurance, Leadership, Survival, Athletics, Persuasion, Defense. Personality traits: Serious, Principled, Conservative, Community-minded, Leader, Disciplined, Patient, Proud (Pretentious), Cautious, Hardworking.

docs.title: Undine
docs.text:
Undines are semi-aquatic beings shaped by ancient oceanic magic, capable of shifting their lower body between a sleek piscine tail and a pair of scaled, amphibious legs. This adaptation allows them to walk on land with surprising agility, though never without discomfort: Undines are biologically and psychologically bound to water. Without regular immersion or at least sustained contact with moisture, they grow anxious, then disoriented, and after a week of complete dryness, their bodies begin to fail.

Their underwater cities—grown from coral, living stone, and bioluminescent reefs—follow the principle of harmonic flow, a philosophy teaching that decisions must align with emotional and environmental currents. This gives Undines an air of serenity and contemplation, though their communication, rich in subtle gestures and shifts of “emotional currents,” often perplexes surface-dwellers.

While generally peaceful, they are not passive: Undines possess long memories and a wary eye toward land cultures. Some live as emissaries or negotiators between sea and shore, but most prefer the safety of their submerged sanctuaries, venturing onto land only with purpose—and always keeping a path back to the water.

Skills: Spellcasting, Swimming, Survival, Craftsmanship, Defense, Negotiation, Persuasion, Tactical. Personality traits: Calm, Measured, Patient, Principled, Community-minded, Welcoming, Cautious, Modest, Sensitive, Organized.

Strong attributes: Perception, Willpower Weak attributes: None Birth attributes: Stature 9~10, Height 9~10, Ego 8~10, Appearance 10~12, Luck 10~11, Balance 10~11 (Prefered) Allegiance: Neutral, Nature, Source, Magic Living environment: Marine Family: Marine Beings / Semies

docs.title: Drakkan
docs.text:
The Drakkan are descendants of ancient dragons whose origins stretch so far back in time that no living people can recount them with certainty. Their existence predates most written histories, and even the oldest traditions speak of them only in fragments—stories of great wyrms who once walked the world and left behind mortal offspring. Whether these dragons took physical form, shifted shapes, or begot children through more mystical means is unknown; what remains undeniable is that the Drakkan carry the unmistakable mark of dragonkind.

Recognizable by their horns, scaled skin, powerful physiques, tails, and vestigial wings, Drakkan embody the traits of the Primordial Dragons they descend from. Each lineage reflects the temperament of its progenitor: fiery ambition from Tiamat, resilience and wisdom from Prometheus, cunning fluidity from Leviathan, competitive energy from Aquilon, sharp insight or shadowed instinct from Bahamut, rigid justice from Chromium, or mystical intellect from Arcanum.

Their past is heavy. Long ago, Drakkan civilizations rose to frightening heights, driven by pride, power, or loyalty to their draconic blood. Their wars—sometimes among themselves, sometimes against other peoples—were so devastating that entire nations united simply to survive them. Though these conflicts are long gone, the memory persists. Many Drakkan today bear the burden of that legacy, living under suspicion or outright fear from other cultures.

Drakkan communities are rare and scattered. Some embrace ancient customs; others reject their heritage, attempting to build humbler lives far from the weight of legend. A few even try to restore a lost sense of honor, arguing that the sins of their ancestors should not define them. Yet everywhere they go, their lineage precedes them—respected by some, distrusted by many, and treated as living artifacts of an age forgotten.

The Primordial Dragons themselves have vanished, believed by scholars either dead, slumbering, or wandering worlds beyond reach. Drakkan grow up surrounded by tales of these forebears, though none can claim to truly know them. Still, denying the connection is considered foolish—perhaps even dangerous—for it is said that nothing angers a Drakkan more than mocking the truth they carry in their blood.

Personality traits: Depends on heritage (spawn type) Strong attributes: Depends on heritage (spawn type) Weak attributes: Depends on heritage (spawn type) Birth attributes: Stature 11~12, Height 11~12, Ego 11~12, Appearance 6~8, Luck 6~8, Balance 10~11

Highly persuasive and influential, they dominate through combat skills (Melee, Brawl) and tactical prowess. Magic is also present, often tied to fire. Subtle, persuasive, and opportunistic, they rely on finesse and survival skills to adapt to any situation. Strong attributes: Dexterity, Intelligence Environment: Waters and cold lands/places Chromatic Blood Domain: Water or Cold Skills: Swimming, Acrobatics, Melee, Subterfuge, Persuasion, Finesse, Brawl, Survival.

Yellow (Aquilon): Children of the dragon of skies, they are energetic, social, and adept at trade interactions. Athletic and competitive, they excel in physical skills (Athletics, Acrobatics) and are strong leaders with a social edge (Persuasion, Negotiation). Strong attributes: Agility, Cunning Environment: Windy and high grounds/places Chromatic Blood Domain: Wind or Lightning Skills: Athletics, Melee, Persuasion, Finesse, Leadership, Acrobatics, Negotiation, Survival.

Black (Bahamut): Children of the dragon of chaos and shadows, they are cunning and adept at subterfuge. Skilled in spellcrafting and tactical arts, they are formidable manipulators and stealth combatants, known for their survival instincts and strategic prowess. Strong attributes: Two different physical attributes Environment: Filthy or dark places/places Chromatic Blood Domain: Darkness or Death or Chaos Skills: Subterfuge, Melee, Tactical, Discretion, Persuasion, Brawl, Spellcrafting, Survival.

White (Chromium): Children of the dragon of virtue and justice, these Spawns are eloquent, disciplined, and dedicated defenders. Highly respected, they focus on defense, leadership, and strategy (Tactical), complemented by magic to uphold order. Purple (Arcanum): Descendants of the dragon of sorcery and mysticism, they are wise, scholarly, and possess strong magical abilities (Spellcasting, Spellcrafting). Drawn to erudition and meditation, they are mystics and artisans in pursuit of knowledge and mastery of the arcane. docs.title: Ogren
docs.text:
Ogrens are massive (gargantuan even) humanoids, descended from ancient ogres yet far more structured and civilized than their monstrous kin. Their imposing physiques, ritual markings, and sheer presence command attention. Though often perceived as brutes, Ogrens possess a practical, earthy intelligence shaped by survival rather than theory.

They inhabit harsh deserts and mountains, living in tight-knit clans centered around endurance, strength, and ancestral trials. To an Ogren, identity is earned through hardship: surviving the world is a rite in itself. While their past conflicts with other peoples have given them an intimidating reputation, those who look beyond their size discover a loyal, honest folk—remarkably skilled in stonecraft, forging, and pragmatic engineering.

Ogrens are towering survivors defined by durability and brute strength. Their weaknesses lie not in courage but in inner instability and a lifetime of hardship, reflected in low Balance and Luck.

Not to be confused with ogre, which is a monstrous version of this people.

Skills: Melee, Endurance, Brawl, Craftsmanship, Defense, Survival, Athletics, Tactical. Personality traits: Imposing, Aggressive, Hardworking, Loyal, Direct (Rude), Reckless, Community-minded, Stubborn, Fearless, Resourceful.

Strong attributes: Strength, Constitution (x2), Willpower Strength – Their immense musculature grants them overwhelming physical power. Constitution (x2) – Ogrens possess exceptional endurance and resilience, capable of withstanding tremendous physical strain. Willpower – Their survivalist culture forges unbreakable determination and mental toughness. Weak attributes: Dexterity, Agility, Luck Dexterity – Their large hands and massive frames limit fine motor skills and delicate movements. Balance – Ogrens are powerful but lack inner harmony; they are vulnerable to fatigue, spiritual strain, and corruptive influences. Luck – Misfortune follows their people; life is a constant trial, rarely eased by favorable chance. Birth attributes: Stature 12~14, Height 12~14, Ego 8~9, Appearance 6~8, Luck 6~8, Balance 10~11 (Prefered) Allegiance: Neutral, Chaos, Ankou, Ambition Living environment: Desert or Mountain Family: Gargantuan Beings / Aberrations

Birth particularities: Vermine - High Natural Regeneration - Reserve Stock - Force of Nature - Oversized Tool Bearer

Cultural particularities: - Peril Affinity - Strive Affinity - Fatigueless - Debt of Pain

docs.title: Orkkan
docs.text:
Orkkans, sometimes called “half-orcs,” are a warrior people shaped by relentless environments and an even harsher history. Their powerful frames, pronounced tusks, and resilient skin speak of a life defined by struggle. In Orkkan society, adversity is not merely endured—it is honored. Strength, rivalry, and tenacity form the core of their culture.

Primarily nomadic, Orkkans travel across deserts, jungles, coasts, and underground territories, adapting with surprising ease. Their long-standing conflicts with humans have created mutual mistrust, passed down through generations. Yet Orkkans are far from mindless brutes: they possess a fierce sense of honor, deep clan loyalty, and a cultural respect for those who prove themselves through action rather than words.

Orkkans are fierce, fast, and durable, thriving in adversity. Their impulsiveness and tumultuous past diminish their Wisdom, Intelligence, and Luck, grounding them as proud survivors shaped by struggle.

Not to be confused with orcs, which is a monstrous version of this people.

Skills: Melee, Endurance, Tactical, Leadership, Brawl, Athletics, Defense, Survival. Personality traits: Aggressive, Fearless, Rebellious, Loyal, Energetic, Reckless, Community-minded, Stubborn, Competitive (Ambitious), Impatient.

Strong attributes: Strength, Agility, Constitution Strength – Their warrior heritage gives them outstanding physical might. Constitution – Orkkans endure extremes of climate, conflict, and deprivation. Agility – Despite their size, they are surprisingly agile and efficient in motion. Weak attributes: Intelligence, Wisdom, Luck Wisdom – Their impulsive, rivalry-driven culture leaves little room for introspection. Intelligence – Orkkans value instinct over analysis, limiting scholarly or strategic reasoning. Luck – Their history is marked by conflict, exile, and systemic misfortune; fate rarely favors them. Birth attributes: Stature 11~13, Height 11~13, Ego 10~12, Appearance 4~7, Luck 8~10, Balance 8~10 (Prefered) Allegiance: Neutral, Chaos, Ankou, Ambition Living environment: Rural, Desert, Nomadic, Marine, or Subterranean Family: Aberrations

Birth particularities: Aberration - Favored Save : Thoughness - Favored Recovery : Vitality (PV) - Steady Hands - Last Stand

Cultural particularities: - Rivality Affinity - Adversity Affinity - Vermin Instinct - Human Animosity - Dwarf Animosity - Terrible Presence - Wild Urges

docs.title: Gablin
docs.text:
Gablins, civilized cousins of monstrous goblins, are small, sharp-minded, and irrepressibly resourceful. Quick of hand and quicker of wit, they thrive in cramped alleys, bustling cities, and subterranean networks. Their society revolves around improvisation, cunning, and adaptability—traits that let them survive where others falter.

Although often mistrusted, Gablins maintain complex social structures based on extended families or craft-and-thief guilds. They excel in improvised engineering, erratic chemistry, stealth, negotiation, and the creative reinterpretation of ownership. Where something needs fixing, repurposing, acquiring, or quietly relocating, a Gablin is rarely far behind—usually grinning while doing it.

Gablins thrive on improvisation, speed, and cleverness. Their weaknesses stem from physical frailty and an inherently unstable inner nature, making them brilliant but fragile opportunists.

Not to be confused with goblins, which is a monstrous version of this people.

Skills: Larceny, Discretion, Subterfuge, Survival, Acrobatics, Brawl, Finesse, Negotiation. Personality traits: Opportunistic, Curious, Resourceful, Spontaneous, Talkative (Loudmouth), Chaotic, Cautious, Envious, Independent, Playful.

Strong attributes: Dexterity, Agility, Cunning, Logic Dexterity – Nimble-fingered and precise, Gablins excel at tinkering, theft, and improvised engineering. Agility – Quick, reactive, and restless, they move with remarkable speed for their size. Cunning – Their sharp intuition allows them to improvise solutions instantly. Logic – Despite their chaotic methods, Gablins possess a strange but effective technical reasoning. Weak attributes: Strength, Willpower, Charisma, Balance Strength – Small bodies and limited muscle mass restrict physical force. Willpower – Their volatile temperament makes them easily distracted, anxious, or overwhelmed. Charisma – Their abrasive mannerisms, erratic behavior, and unsettling energy often make them distrusted or poorly received by others. Birth attributes: Stature 6~8, Height 6~8, Ego 11~13, Appearance 6~8, Luck 11~13, Balance 11~13 (Prefered) Allegiance: Neutral, Chaos, Reason, Steam Living environment: Rural, Desert, Nomadic, Marine, or Subterranean Family: Aberrations

Birth particularities: Aberration - Favored Save : Reflexes - Scapegoats - Coward Insights

Cultural particularities: - Escape Affinity - Treachery Affinity - Vermin Instinct - Dwarf Animosity - Miserable Presence - Resourceful - Not Picky - Scavenger

docs.title: Tail
docs.text: The character possesses a functional tail fully integrated into their anatomy, allowing improved balance, spatial awareness, and natural rear coverage in physical situations. Effect: The tail may be used as an additional limb, limited by a dedicated skill acting as a cap (similar to ambidexterity). It cannot wield tools or manufactured weapons, restricting combat actions to natural weapons only. The tail counts as a natural weapon based on AGI, and the character suffers no penalties when attacked from behind or when flanked.

docs.title: Horns
docs.text: The character bears prominent horns that extend their body's natural lethality and reinforce their presence in close combat encounters. Effect: The horns count as natural weapons usable without equipment. Horn-based attacks are treated as natural weapon attacks (attribute is typically STR) and may be used for actions such as charges or headbutts.

docs.title: Winged Creature
docs.text: The character possesses fully developed wings adapted for sustained aerial movement and precise control while flying. Effect: The character gains the ability to fly, benefits from good maneuverability while airborne (180°), and unlocks the Flight skill.

docs.title: Amphibious
docs.text: The character has biological adaptations that allow them to function efficiently in aquatic environments, including prolonged underwater activity. Effect: The character gains good maneuverability while swimming (180°), can hold their breath far longer than a standard individual, and gains advantage on Swimming-related tests.

docs.title: Quadruped
docs.text: The character moves using four limbs dedicated to locomotion, providing exceptional stability, speed, and resistance to displacement. Effect: The character gains +5 Defense against knockdown and push effects. When performing movement actions, they may replace one Simple Action with one Free Action, and they gain advantage on Running-related tests.

docs.title: Favored Recovery (Vitality)
docs.text: The character naturally recovers from physical harm more efficiently than most, enduring restorative procedures with reduced strain. Effect: Vitality (PV) recovery is increased by +2. When the character receives healing to Vitality that generates Fatigue (typically from non-natural sources), the Fatigue threshold is increased by +1 (1 Fatigue per 3 points recovered instead of the default).

docs.title: Favored Recovery (Endurance)
docs.text: The character replenishes their physical stamina more efficiently, allowing sustained effort with reduced exhaustion. Effect: Endurance (PE) recovery is increased by +2. When the character receives healing to Endurance that generates Fatigue, the Fatigue threshold is increased by +1.

docs.title: Favored Recovery (Karma)
docs.text: The character's fortune and destiny realign more easily, smoothing the strain caused by forced or accelerated recovery. Effect: Karma (PK) recovery is increased by +2. When the character receives healing to Karma that generates Fatigue, the Fatigue threshold is increased by +1.

docs.title: Favored Recovery (Spirituality)
docs.text: The character's spiritual essence stabilizes quickly after depletion, resisting backlash from restorative effects. Effect: Spirituality (PS) recovery is increased by +2. When the character receives healing to Spirituality that generates Fatigue, the Fatigue threshold is increased by +1.

docs.title: Favored Recovery (Mana)
docs.text: The character channels arcane energies more safely, recovering magical reserves with reduced exhaustion. Effect: Mana (PM) recovery is increased by +2. When the character receives healing to Mana that generates Fatigue, the Fatigue threshold is increased by +1.

docs.title: Favored Recovery (Chi)
docs.text: The character's internal energy flows more harmoniously, allowing accelerated recovery with less physical or spiritual strain. Effect: Chi (PC) recovery is increased by +2. When the character receives healing to Chi that generates Fatigue, the Fatigue threshold is increased by +1.

docs.title: Favored Save (Fortune)
docs.text: The character is naturally protected by luck or destiny when facing unpredictable outcomes. Effect: Fortune Saves are increased by +1.

docs.title: Favored Save (Composure)
docs.text: The character maintains emotional control under pressure more reliably than most. Effect: Composure Saves are increased by +1.

docs.title: Favored Save (Insight)
docs.text: The character resists deception, illusion, and misdirection with heightened clarity of mind. Effect: Insight Saves are increased by +1.

docs.title: Favored Save (Determination)
docs.text: The character's willpower allows them to endure coercion, fear, and mental strain more effectively. Effect: Determination Saves are increased by +1.

docs.title: Favored Save (Prestige)
docs.text: The character's social standing and force of presence shield them against reputational or authority-based threats. Effect: Prestige Saves are increased by +1.

docs.title: Favored Save (Toughness)
docs.text: The character's body withstands physical punishment and harmful effects better than average. Effect: Toughness Saves are increased by +1.

docs.title: Favored Save (Reflexes)
docs.text: The character reacts instinctively to danger, avoiding sudden threats with superior reflexes. Effect: Reflexes Saves are increased by +1.

docs.title: Favored Save (Opposition)
docs.text: The character excels at actively resisting external forces, particularly supernatural intrusions. Effect: Opposition Saves are increased by +1. This bonus also applies to other Saves when they are used specifically to counter magical effects.

docs.title: Exemplary
docs.text: Raised as a model individual within their people, the character embodies discipline, cultural standards, and social expectations. Effect: The character gains +1 PP.

docs.title: Human Ingenuity
docs.text: Humans display remarkable adaptability, either by accumulating raw potential or by excelling naturally in a specific type of situation shaped by their culture. Effect: The character gains +10 PA, or selects one Aura (see Auras below).

docs.title: Secondary Specialty
docs.text: The character diversifies their expertise beyond their initial focus, developing a second domain of specialization. Effect: The character gains one additional Specialty. This Specialty must meet the same requirements as the first one.

docs.title: Accelerated Learning
docs.text: Humans learn quickly through experience, adapting faster than most to new challenges and disciplines. Effect: The character gains +20 PX.

docs.title: Auras
docs.text: An Aura represents a natural human excellence in a specific type of situation. When an Aura applies, the character's natural Prowess for the relevant test is increased by +2, allowing the expenditure of up to 2 PC to gain up to +2 adjustments.

docs.title: Singularities-Based Auras
docs.text: Aura Applies When the Test… Excellence Would result in a critical success Heroicness Displays an exploit Steadiness Displays clumsiness or a fumble Providence Displays a strike of luck Destiny Is rerolled through Karma Stubbornness Is attempted again after a previous failure Altruism Benefits others but not the character Audacity Is performed against a figure of authority (in combat, only the leader qualifies)

docs.title: Save-Based Auras
docs.text: Aura Associated Save Hardiness Robustness Swiftness Reflexes Unyieldingness Determination Stressless Composure Fatefulness Fortune Insightfulness Intuition Adverseness Opposition Authority Prestige (first contact with NPCs only)

docs.title: Ancestral
docs.text: The character carries an ancient lineage that instinctively resists supernatural interference with the mind and emotions. Effect: The character may reroll tests made to resist magical charms, illusions, and other magical effects that alter the mind or emotions.

docs.title: Far Sight
docs.text: The character perceives the world with exceptional clarity, effortlessly noticing distant details that would escape most individuals. Effect: All perception distances and ranged attack distances are increased by 50%. When precise measurement is unnecessary, the character is simply considered to see farther and more clearly than average.

docs.title: Night Vision
docs.text: The character's eyes are adapted to low-light environments, allowing them to function effectively in darkness. Effect: The character can see in dim light and darkness, but not in total darkness. Penalties caused by low light are reduced by 3, but penalties caused by complete darkness are not reduced.

docs.title: Song of the Earth
docs.text: By attuning themselves to a place through quiet communion, the character harmonizes with its subtle rhythms and energies. Effect: The character may spend a short uninterrupted period alone to attune to a specific location (typically limited to a single room). Until attuned to another location, the character gains +1 to all tests performed there. If the location is natural, this bonus becomes +2. During attunement, the character cannot perform any other action.

docs.title: Focus
docs.text: Through deep concentration, the character can momentarily sharpen their perception and execution. Effect: Once per day, the character may reroll one chosen skill test.

docs.title: Soul Connection
docs.text: The character forges profound emotional bonds that transcend distance, manifesting as a constant awareness of those they are linked to. Effect: The character may designate up to three individuals as soul-linked. They continuously perceive their general state, emotions, and relative orientation (and roughly their distance). This bond must be based on genuine attachment and cannot be formed casually.

docs.title: Light Feets
docs.text: The character moves with supernatural lightness, barely disturbing the surface they tread upon. Effect: The character may walk on water, sinking only once their movement ends. They ignore movement penalties and terrain-based damage, provided they do not end their turn on damaging terrain.

docs.title: Yoke of the Waters
docs.text: The character's body requires constant contact with water to function properly, binding their survival to its presence. Effect: Each day after the first without significant skin contact with water imposes a –1 penalty to Constitution, worsening daily until death if deprivation continues. In exchange, while properly hydrated, the character gains +1 Fortune.

docs.title: Impervious
docs.text: The character's body partially absorbs hostile energies, dulling their impact. Effect: The character gains minor resistance to all energy types, reducing such damage by 25%.

docs.title: Forgettable Presence
docs.text: When nothing about the character stands out, their presence slips easily from memory. Effect: If the character's appearance and behavior are unremarkable, witnesses cannot recall their presence afterward. In combat, the character may halve their menace if they choose to activate this effect.

docs.title: Shadow Walker
docs.text: The character blends instinctively with shadows, moving unseen where others could not. Effect: The character may attempt to hide in conditions that would normally make hiding impossible, except in completely bare and well-lit spaces. Under favorable conditions, hiding attempts are made with advantage. In combat, menace may be halved if the effect is activated.

docs.title: Soiled Soul
docs.text: The character’s soul has been permanently tainted, bearing scars that cannot be fully cleansed. This corruption does not dominate them outright, but it leaves a lingering imprint that makes them more tolerant—and more vulnerable—to its influence. Effect: The character’s maximum Corruption threshold is increased by +2.

docs.title: Grace
docs.text: The character turns successful evasions into lethal opportunities. Effect: When the character successfully dodges an attack or tactic, they may mark the attacker. Only one target may be marked at a time, and the mark ends at the end of the scene. The character gains a reroll on their next attack or tactical combat action against the marked target.

docs.title: Payback
docs.text: Pain sharpens the character's resolve, fueling precise retaliation. Effect: When the character is hit, they may mark the attacker. Only one target may be marked at a time, and the mark ends at the end of the scene. The character gains a reroll on their next attack or tactical combat action against the marked target.

docs.title: Neverending Hope
docs.text: Even in despair, the character draws strength from loss, turning suffering into resolve. Effect: Initiative is increased by +1 for every 5 total points of Spirituality (PS) and Vitality (PV) lost so far, up to a maximum of +5.

docs.title: Dark Surge
docs.text: A dormant and unsettling power lurks within the character, awakening in moments of emotional or existential strain. Effect: The precise effects of Dark Surge are defined by the setting and campaign tone, typically granting heightened power at a significant narrative or mechanical cost.

docs.title: Cantrips
docs.text: The character instinctively channels minor magical effects without formal training. Effect: The character may cast level 0 spells as if they had proper access to magic. The magical tradition is chosen among those associated with the character's primary attribute. Maximum Mana (PM) is equal to half the normal maximum. The character may only access one domain or skill. If the character later gains a domain through a proper tradition, maximum PM is recalculated using the higher value, and all spells from that domain may be cast at orison level.

docs.title: Magic Attunement
docs.text: The character resonates deeply with a specific branch of magic. Effect: The character selects one magic domain. When casting spells from this domain, each die rolled has a minimum value of 3. When spells from this domain are used against the character, each die rolled has a maximum value of 5.

docs.title: Magic Tongue
docs.text: The character can sense and convey the immediate intentions of magically attuned beings. Effect: The character may imperfectly understand or transmit basic intentions to creatures possessing a magic attribute. Complex or abstract concepts cannot be conveyed.

docs.title: Beast Tongue
docs.text: The character communicates instinctively with terrestrial and aerial beasts, including feral creatures. Effect: As Magic Tongue, but applies to beasts.

docs.title: Fish Tongue
docs.text: The character shares a primal understanding with aquatic creatures and amphibious peoples. Effect: As Magic Tongue, but applies to aquatic creatures and amphibious ancestries.

docs.title: Spirit Tongue
docs.text: The character perceives the intent of spirits and creatures bound to darkness and the unseen. Effect: As Magic Tongue, but applies to spirits, vermin, infernal creatures, and creatures adapted to darkness.

docs.title: Monster Tongue
docs.text: The character understands the raw instincts of monstrous beings. Effect: As Magic Tongue, but applies to monsters, including semi-monsters.

docs.title: Dragon Tongue
docs.text: The character can perceive the immediate intent of draconic beings. Effect: As Magic Tongue, but applies to dragons and drakkans.

docs.title: Tireless Fortitude
docs.text: Dwarves endure combat through sheer resilience, wearing down their enemies through unwavering toughness. Effect: All attack, defense, and tactical rolls made by opponents against the character are reduced by 1 during combat.

docs.title: Financial Acumen
docs.text: The character possesses a natural sense for value, profit, and material worth. Effect: The character gains 5% more money from all monetary gains.

docs.title: Infra Vision
docs.text: The character's eyes are adapted to low-light environments, allowing effective perception underground and in darkness. Effect: The character can see in dim light and darkness, but not in total darkness. Penalties caused by low light are reduced by 3, while penalties caused by complete darkness are not reduced.

docs.title: Expansive Memory
docs.text: The character's memory is exceptionally reliable, capable of retaining vast amounts of technical, historical, or practical information. Effect: The character's Memory score is increased by +5.

docs.title: Forethought
docs.text: The character is habitually prepared, rarely caught without the tools they need. Effect: As long as the character owns the appropriate tools or items and has sufficient inventory space, they are assumed to have them available when needed. No Intuition test is required to determine whether the character remembered to bring necessary equipment.

docs.title: Efficient Repairs
docs.text: Dwarven craftsmanship prioritizes durability and efficiency, especially when restoring damaged equipment. Effect: The cost or the duration of repair actions is halved (player chooses which applies each time).

docs.title: Mercantile Culture
docs.text: Trade and wealth are deeply ingrained in the character's cultural background. Effect: The character gains 5% more money from all monetary gains. This bonus stacks with Financial Acumen.

docs.title: Hardness
docs.text: The character's body is physically dense and resistant to harm. Effect: Physical Protection is increased by +1, and the character can sustain one additional scratch wound.

docs.title: Bloodline Pride
docs.text: The character draws strength and confidence from their lineage, invoking ancestral achievements when it truly matters. Effect: Once per day, if the character meaningfully references their lineage or family accomplishments during a skill test, all dice rolled for that test have a minimum value of 4 (this effect cannot generate singularities). In combat, this may be used, but requires a speech action appropriate to the length of the explanation.

docs.title: Unyielding
docs.text: Refusing to fall, the character clings to consciousness through sheer stubborn will. Effect: Once per scene, when the character would lose their last Vitality (PV) or Spirituality (PS) point, that resource is set to 0 instead of going into negative values.

docs.title: Stubbornness
docs.text: Experience hardens the character against afflictions they have already endured. Effect: The character may reroll a test to resist venom, poison, sickness, curses, or rare conditions that they have already experienced at least once. For common conditions, this applies if the character has experienced the condition earlier in the same scene.
